data.text: Biking the Balkans: What Are Your Thoughts?

Hi everyone - headed over to Europe for my 8th 9-10 week tour and I just wanted to ask - What are your feelings about biking in Poland, the Balkan and the Baltic states, and the other countries that border Ukraine? Is this a bad idea? I have biked these areas in the past but thinking that maybe this summer I stay more in the west. Thoughts? What about Turkey?
Baltic states doesn‚Äôt border Ukraine‚Ä¶ feel free to come!
data.author: Juris Lipsnis

data.text: I know I have cycled in Croatia and Montenegro but not in Bosnia and Serbia - how is it there now ?
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: wait wait! Baltic is Lithuania , Estonia , and Latvia ! I biked in these countries in 2019!
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: You're right it's Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia. Of course we feel that there is war in Ukraine, there are refugees from that country now in Baltics. But everything is calm and safe here.
data.author: Juris Lipsnis

data.text: omg forgive me! it is late here in the USA! üòÜüòÜüòÜ
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: I just came through Croatia, Bosnia, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia. I can't tell from your post what your specific concerns are, but I had a great time in those countries and would highly recommend for bike touring if you are accustomed to places that are a bit rough around the edges, and it sounds like you are. Beautiful terrain, friendly people, interesting culture, very compact so you can cross a whole country in a couple of days if you like, plenty of seldom visited villages and mountains but also cool cities with modern infrastructure.
data.author: Hugh Warrington

data.text: why do you think now something has changed in the Balkans?
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: I think it'd be awesome. I was there in 2019 and it was really good. I was camping on one side of the Bug river one night and could have chucked a rock across into Belarus. If Putrid does anything to a NATO country we're all going to be in the shit so...
data.author: Kerry Palmer

data.text: OMG i was also in the same region in 2019! We biked from Athens to Estonia that year. At one point we stayed in a "bar hotel" at the Belarusian/Polish border thinking we could bike into Belarus the next day. We were naive Americans lol
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: and true about Nato - we are all FU'd if he does something
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: If Pootin tries something really stupid, we'll be in deep s*it regardless where we are at the moment.
data.author: Juris Lipsnis

data.text: i agree! Whether we are in our home country or not, it will be a mess regardless
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: I would stay more to the west or go to Turkey. I think that the facilities or infrastructure might be too full/disrupted. If anyone says that a trip there now would support the economy there, well, make a big a** donation. Your body doesn't have to be there to make a difference.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: i agree!
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: that's definitely a perspective of someone completely not from the area. We in Poland and I believe all the mentioned countries live normal lives. I know the situation is unpredictible but one doesn't have to stick to the eastern border if scared. All the Polish cyclists make plans for the summer. The Balkans on the other hand is still further. I know you are an experienced cyclist but truly can't see your point.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: I laughed when i saw keep to the west.
data.author: Ivan Gorodess

data.text: that's not the first time I see this advice.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: Well, excuse me for considering whether or not there will be room for accommodations when you have an extra few hundred thousand refugees in town who might need it more.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: Wai Sing Lee good point but your comment was not just about accommodation. The Polish proved to be good in taking this into consideration I guess. I simply am not happy to see more information that scare people off. Especially when countries like the Balkans are considered, not involved and put into one pot.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: Accommodations are part of the facilities/infrastructure. But, you also have to think about food, if more and more tourists are there does it increase demand in terms of food and, hence, higher prices for everyone else? I am not here to scare people off, I am just thinking whether or not being there is a negative or positive. As I originally said, if you want to make a positive contribution then just send cash.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: I.am sorry but again, commenting like that just shows that you don't know the reality. Its understandable as seen through the media. Poland has always been much cheaper than the western countries, not mentioning the Balkans. There's enough food!. The situation with accomodation is not good but on rental market as many Ukrainians want to settle. Many people opened their homes do its not like the refugees block the hotels. Happy to receive anyone that wishes to explore, as always.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: its only in that area near the border, Przemysl is a small city and few cyclists would go there unless they're going to Ukraine. and just checking now the situation is currently better. Hostels from $10 a night
data.author: Ivan Gorodess

data.text: Okay...
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: many of refugees are in centers provided for them, in private homes or others. Many have left too. they have not filled what would typically be considered tourist accommodations.
data.author: Ivan Gorodess

data.text: that's what I was saying.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: by the way, maybe you can answer this question. i really like the architecture in Poland, many types of styles, but are these slanted walls considered Polish or is it a support function? thx

data.text: Hey, no I won't answer this. I don't think it's Polish though. Old, renaissance buildings done this way. Interesting point of view!
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: Phew!
data.author: Jean-Marc Combret

data.text: No problem.
data.author: James William Langford

data.text: Poland is safe to cycle. The driving culture is not always the best (like in many other places!) but hopping on some longer bike route should be perfectly fine.
data.author: Agnieszka Sobo≈Ñ

data.text: From what I can see there is a panic when it simply comes to cycling Europe. I know the situation is unpredictible and one might feel concern in cycling/coming to the bordering countries (the reservations for the summer dropped nearly 100% in Poland). I would say - come, no real changes here apart from more accommodation facilities taken as people gave their rooms to the Ukrainians fleeing their country, but its going to change as well (the season starts and the facilities need to earn money). Moreover, the tents solve the problem anyway. And hey, what's the Balkans have to do with it? Well of course if you prefer for the peace of mind going west or to Africa than yes, but myself the Balkans and Poland, the east, that's where I'm going to spend my cycling summer. It's cheap and beautiful.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text:
absolutely no problem You can go right up to the border, there is no difference. i was there for 2 weeks where the refugees are crossing, in Medyka, near Przemysl. Can the war spill over? Yes. Can you get hit by a car tomorrow? A meteor? i went to Przemysl train station where the refugees are sleeping and bought a ticket 45 minutes before the train left. Poland is busy now, there are lots of tourists, Auschwitz, Krakow, Warsaw are busy. There are lots of people including refugees in hostels. The only problem is near Przemysl where accommodations are very limited but even there i found a place to stay. There is war tourism, thousands of people from all over the world are in Poland volunteering. check out booking.com, look at train and bus ticket availability on the net. everyone has their own opinion but i wouldn't let it stop me. Do it while you can, who knows what the world will be like in 6 months
Booking.com: The largest selection of hotels, homes, and vacation rentals
booking.com
data.author: Ivan Gorodess

data.text: I‚Äôm in Poland now and think you would be fine. You may want to stay away from the borders but all else is good.
data.author: Richard Brass

data.text: If you are close to the border with Ukraine and want a hotel it could be tough. There are many NGO‚Äôs taking up the rooms. I was just in Przemysl, Poland and rooms are here to come by. As soon as you leave the border things get back to normal. I believe of you stay 50 miles away from the borders you are good. I would have an edit plan on the event things expand beyond the Ukraine border. If this happens it could get very serious quickly. Putin is unpredictable and most of the military equipment is coming through Poland. If he decides to hit facilities within Poland the entire world is in trouble. One thing for sure is you will see and hear things that are very unified to the time. Last June I toured in Iceland and it was very unique due to the lack of tourist because of Covid. I feel lucky to have experience Iceland like this. Sorry for the reason but no control over that. I was also just up to Gdansk and things seem very normal there. Have a great trip.
data.author: Richard Brass

data.text: Russian submarines just fired a couple of test missiles in the sea of Japan... I think Polands as safe as anywhere.

data.text: its a bit better now. i stayed at noclegi every night,$10
